posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
I’m spinning this off from the Kraken thread…

ngreen had a VERY nice graph showing -significant- current going back into the battery during hard “slam it in reverse” style braking on a MAX Swerve chassis:

Announcing Kraken X60 powered by Talon FX!

I was looking yesterday and was noting the voltage spike during hard reverses on the maxswerve/neo drive.

Responding to his question about traces:

@ngreen , the only traces I can see on there are the red one from CPU and the yellow one for battery Voltage.  In a perfect world I’d love to see the total PDP Amperage and the Amps for one of the drive motors. Assuming 22mOhms of resistance to the ideal battery, those peaks might easily be 181 Amps of braking current!

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
truher:

is there a rule that would keep a team from using flywheel regen to power a short-duration, high-current load?

No, but this would have to be a pretty dang specific application to make any sense. The flywheel is still getting its energy from the battery, and as was pointed out in the other thread, this process is only about 15% efficient. Combine that with the running efficiency of the motors, and you’re dumping a lot more power than you’d otherwise be doing to do the task in a more conventional way.

But, if you have some sort of application in mind that would otherwise brown out the robot for, like, maybe 0.5 seconds… go for it?

It also feels relevant to point out here that the roboRIO is rated for 16.0V. That’s why the graph is cut off there. It also looked like it happened to peak at that voltage, but go any higher and you risk frying something.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
Welllll, i mean, we set our drivetrain current lower than it could be, specifically to avoid browning out all the time so i could imagine a subsystem whose only purpose is “leveling,” using a simple control: if battery voltage seems good, put energy into the flywheel.  if battery voltage seems low, pull energy out of the flywheel.  I think you could actually use SparkMax closed loop control, with a little bit of conditioning on the feedback signal.

A typical brownout event for us is short, like one second long, maybe a deficit of only about 100W during that time, so at 15% efficiency we’d need to pull 800W out of a flywheel, about 60A, which we could do with a 2kg 0.2m ring at 5k rpm, which doesn’t seem crazy.  Does it?  It’s definitely not efficient, but maybe affordable from a total-battery-energy-per-match standpoint?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Oh, wow!  That clears up things nicely!

Yep, that’s a lot of current going back into the battery!

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
truher:

is there a rule that would keep a team from using flywheel regen

You would have to drive the fly wheel through a legal motor into a legal motor controller. Legal firmware would have to be used in the motor controller. An overhauling load like a flywheel turns the motion into electrical energy and heat. Absent a flux capacitor, the energy has to go somewhere. I don’t know how useful this would be in an FRC sense. But then until two year ago, I didn’t think you could use vacuum to make an FRC robot jump.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Carefully managed, I -think- you could get a useful amount of energy storage.  Flywheels aren’t particularly energy dense, so its not going to hold the system up for very long.  BUT, if you had something like an arm-based piece flinger, you could brake your flywheel when you told your flinger to “go” and potentially get a very peppy system

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Other fun voltage ratings, since we’re here:

-REV’s stuff is generally rated up to 18V across the board. The exceptions are the SPARK line (Flex documentation pending), which are rated for 24V functionally and 30V absolute, and the Blinkin.

-CTRE’s are a bit more varied, with the general rule of thumb being 16V functionality for older stuff with an 18V maximum before permanent damage occurs. Talon SRXs and several newer devices, like the Pigeon 2.0, are rated for up to 28V. (Curiously, the Falcon 500 manual does not give a maximum voltage rating for the Talon FX.)

Now, given how worst (best?) case @ngreen ’s testing was, I don’t think any team trying to take advantage of this should be that concerned. However, it’s worth noting that the resistance of the power path from the PDP through the battery will impact this; the higher it is, the higher the voltage from this effect can get. If that test was from a particularly healthy battery, I’d be a little concerned about the effects from a more middling one.

truher:

Welllll, i mean, we set our drivetrain current lower than it could be, specifically to avoid browning out all the time so i could imagine a subsystem whose only purpose is “leveling,” using a simple control: if battery voltage seems good, put energy into the flywheel. if battery voltage seems low, pull energy out of the flywheel. I think you could actually use SparkMax closed loop control, with a little bit of conditioning on the feedback signal.

A typical brownout event for us is short, like one second long, maybe a deficit of only about 100W during that time, so at 15% efficiency we’d need to pull 800W out of a flywheel, about 60A, which we could do with a 2kg 0.2m ring at 5k rpm , which doesn’t seem crazy. Does it? It’s definitely not efficient, but maybe affordable from a total-battery-energy-per-match standpoint?

You’d be creating a bad feedback loop here. The more energy you drain from the battery, the lower the resting voltage gets. If you actually use this thing, and then spend the energy to recover the flywheel, you’re quickly going to need it more and more just driving around.

Not to mention, voltage gets low enough driving around that you would probably only spin the wheel up when stationary or driving very slowly, like during alignment.

Keeping the flywheel spinning isn’t free either. It’s not much, but it’s not nothing.

I think having this as a dedicated always-on subsystem is likely to cause more power issues than it solves. The hyper-niche use case of using the voltage spike to very briefly draw more than usual current for a planned task actually seems more viable to me, though I struggle to think of an application in the last few seasons where it really would’ve helped very much.

It also feels relevant to point out here that the roboRIO is rated for 16.0V. That’s why the graph is cut off there. It also looked like it happened to peak at that voltage, but go any higher and you risk frying something.
